ai_summary.Messages: {"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: [ { "sha": "b1c4629c38ec990f609f6004857ddd374f75e335", "filename": "docs/architecture/recover-from-deletions.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 73, "deletions": 45, "changes": 118, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Farchitecture%2Frecover-from-deletions.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Farchitecture%2Frecover-from-deletions.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Farchitecture%2Frecover-from-deletions.md?ref=73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587", "patch": "@@ -1,26 +1,25 @@\n ---\n title: Recover from deletions in Microsoft Entra ID\n-description: Learn how to recover from unintended deletions.\n+description: Understand the difference between soft and hard deletions and how to recover or recreate objects in Microsoft Entra ID.\n author: janicericketts\n manager: martinco\n ms.service: entra\n ms.subservice: architecture\n ms.topic: article\n-ms.date: 11/14/2022\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n ms.author: jricketts\n ms.reviewer: jricketts\n ms.custom: sfi-image-nochange\n ---\n-\n # Recover from deletions\n \n-This article addresses recovering from soft and hard deletions in your Microsoft Entra tenant. If you haven't already done so, read [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md) for foundational knowledge.\n+Managing deletions in Microsoft Entra ID is a critical aspect of maintaining the integrity and availability of your organization's identity infrastructure. This article provides a comprehensive guide to understand the differences between soft and hard deletions, monitor for deletions, and recover or recreate objects in your Microsoft Entra tenant. Whether you're dealing with accidental deletions or preparing recovery strategies, this guide equips you with the knowledge and tools to minimize disruption and ensure continuity. For foundational insights, start with [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md).\n \n ## Monitor for deletions\n \n-The [Microsoft Entra audit log](~/identity/monitoring-health/concept-audit-logs.md) contains information on all delete operations performed in your tenant. Export these logs to a security information and event management tool such as [Microsoft Sentinel](/azure/sentinel/overview).\n+The [Microsoft Entra audit log](~/identity/monitoring-health/concept-audit-logs.md) contains information on all delete operations performed in your tenant. Export these logs to a security information and event management tool, such as [Microsoft Sentinel](/azure/sentinel/overview).\n \n-You can also use Microsoft Graph to audit changes and build a custom solution to monitor differences over time. For more information on how to find deleted items by using Microsoft Graph, see [List deleted items - Microsoft Graph v1.0](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-list?tabs=http).\n+Use Microsoft Graph to audit changes, and build a custom solution to monitor differences over time. For more information on how to find deleted items by using Microsoft Graph, see [List deleted items - Microsoft Graph v1.0](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-list?tabs=http).\n \n ### Audit log\n \n@@ -41,60 +40,61 @@ A delete event for applications, users, and Microsoft 365 Groups is a soft delet\n | All other objects| Delete \"objectType\"| Hard deleted |\n \n > [!NOTE]\n-> The Audit log doesn't distinguish the group type of a deleted group. Only Microsoft 365 Groups are soft deleted. If you see a Delete group entry, it might be the soft delete of a Microsoft 365 Group or the hard delete of another type of group.\n+> The audit log doesn't distinguish the group type of a deleted group. Only Microsoft 365 Groups are soft deleted. If you see a Delete group entry, it might be the soft delete of a Microsoft 365 Group or the hard delete of another type of group.\n >\n >*It's important that your documentation of your known good state includes the group type for each group in your organization*. To learn more about documenting your known good state, see [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md).\n \n ### Monitor support tickets\n \n-A sudden increase in support tickets about access to a specific object might indicate that a deletion occurred. Because some objects have dependencies, deletion of a group used to access an application, an application itself, or a Conditional Access policy that targets an application can all cause broad sudden impact. If you see a trend like this, check to ensure that none of the objects required for access were deleted.\n+A sudden increase in support tickets about access to a specific object might indicate that a deletion happened. Because some objects have dependencies, deleting a group used to access an application, an application itself, or a Conditional Access policy that targets an application can cause broad, sudden impact. If you see a trend like this, check to ensure that none of the objects required for access were deleted.\n \n ## Soft deletions\n \n-When objects such as users, Microsoft 365 Groups, or application registrations are soft deleted, they enter a suspended state in which they aren't available for use by other services. In this state, items retain their properties and can be restored for 30 days. After 30 days, objects in the soft-deleted state are permanently, or hard, deleted.\n+When objects such as users, Microsoft 365 Groups, or application registrations are soft deleted, they enter a suspended state in which they aren't available for use by other services. In this state, items keep their properties and can be restored for 30 days. After 30 days, objects in the soft-deleted state are permanently deleted or hard deleted.\n \n > [!NOTE]\n-> Objects can't be restored from a hard-deleted state. They must be re-created and reconfigured.\n+> Objects can't be restored from a hard-deleted state. Re-create and reconfigure them.\n \n-### When soft deletes occur\n+\n+### When soft deletes happen\n \n-It's important to understand why object deletions occur in your environment so that you can prepare for them. This section outlines frequent scenarios for soft deletion by object class. You might see scenarios that are unique to your organization, so a discovery process is key to preparation.\n+Understanding why object deletions happen in your environment helps you prepare for them. This section outlines frequent scenarios for soft deletion by object class. You might see scenarios that are unique to your organization, so a discovery process is key to preparation.\n \n ### Users\n \n-Users enter the soft-delete state anytime the user object is deleted by using the Azure portal, Microsoft Graph, or PowerShell.\n+Users enter a soft-deleted state when the user object is deleted using the Microsoft Entra admin center, Microsoft Graph, or PowerShell.\n \n-The most frequent scenarios for user deletion are:\n+Common scenarios for deleting users include:\n \n-* An administrator intentionally deletes a user in the Azure portal in response to a request or as part of routine user maintenance.\n-* An automation script in Microsoft Graph or PowerShell triggers the deletion. For example, you might have a script that removes users who haven't signed in for a specified time.\n-* A user is moved out of scope for synchronization with Microsoft Entra Connect.\n-* A user is removed from an HR system and is deprovisioned via an automated workflow.\n+* An administrator deletes a user in the Microsoft Entra admin center in response to a request or as part of routine user maintenance.\n+* An automation script in Microsoft Graph or PowerShell triggers the deletion. For example, you might have a script that removes users who don't sign in for a specified time.\n+* A user moves out of scope for synchronization with Microsoft Entra Connect.\n+* A user retires, is removed from an HR system, and is deprovisioned via an automated workflow.\n \n ### Microsoft 365 Groups\n \n-The most frequent scenarios for Microsoft 365 Groups being deleted are:\n+The most frequent scenarios for deleting Microsoft 365 Groups are:\n \n * An administrator intentionally deletes the group, for example, in response to a support request.\n-* An automation script in Microsoft Graph or PowerShell triggers the deletion. For example, you might have a script that deletes groups that haven't been accessed or attested to by the group owner for a specified time.\n+* An automation script in Microsoft Graph or PowerShell triggers the deletion. For example, you might have a script that deletes groups that aren't accessed or attested to by the group owner for a specified time.\n * Unintentional deletion of a group owned by non-admins.\n \n ### Application objects and service principals\n \n-The most frequent scenarios for application deletion are:\n+The most frequent scenarios for deleting applications are:\n \n * An administrator intentionally deletes the application, for example, in response to a support request.\n * An automation script in Microsoft Graph or PowerShell triggers the deletion. For example, you might want a process for deleting abandoned applications that are no longer used or managed. In general, create an offboarding process for applications rather than scripting to avoid unintentional deletions.\n \n-When you delete an application, the application registration by default enters the soft-delete state. To understand the relationship between application registrations and service principals, see [Apps and service principals in Microsoft Entra ID - Microsoft identity platform](~/identity-platform/app-objects-and-service-principals.md).\n+When you delete an application, the application registration by default enters the soft-deleted state. To understand the relationship between application registrations and service principals, see [Apps and service principals in Microsoft Entra ID - Microsoft identity platform](~/identity-platform/app-objects-and-service-principals.md).\n \n ### Administrative units\n \n-The most common scenario for deletions is when administrative units (AU) are deleted by accident, although still needed. \n+The most common scenario for deletions is when administrative units are accidentally deleted but still needed. \n \n ## Recover from soft deletion\n \n-You can restore soft-deleted items in the administrative portal, or by using Microsoft Graph. Not all object classes can manage soft-delete capabilities in the portal, some are only listed, viewed, hard deleted, or restored using the deletedItems Microsoft Graph API.\n+Not all object classes manage soft-delete capabilities in the Microsoft Entra admin center. Some are only listed, viewed, hard deleted, or restored using the deletedItems Microsoft Graph API.\n \n ### Properties maintained with soft delete\n \n@@ -104,13 +104,14 @@ You can restore soft-deleted items in the administrative portal, or by using Mic\n |Microsoft 365 Groups|All properties maintained, including ObjectID, group memberships, licenses, and application assignments|\n |Application registration | All properties maintained. See more information after this table.|\n |Service principal|All properties maintained|\n-|Administrative unit (AU)|All properties maintained|\n+|Administrative unit|All properties maintained|\n+|Conditional Access policies|All properties maintained|\n+|Named locations|All properties maintained|\n \n ### Users\n \n You can see soft-deleted users in the Azure portal on the **Users | Deleted users** page.\n \n-\n For more information on how to restore users, see the following documentation:\n \n * To restore from the Azure portal, see [Restore or permanently remove recently deleted user](~/fundamentals/users-restore.md).\n@@ -129,61 +130,88 @@ For more information on how to restore soft-deleted Microsoft 365 Groups, see th\n \n ### Applications and service principals\n \n-Applications have two objects: the application registration and the service principal. For more information on the differences between the registration and the service principal, see [Apps and service principals in Microsoft Entra ID](~/identity-platform/app-objects-and-service-principals.md).\n+Applications include two objects: the application registration and the service principal. For more information on the differences between the registration and the service principal, see [Apps and service principals in Microsoft Entra ID](~/identity-platform/app-objects-and-service-principals.md).\n \n-To restore an application from the Azure portal, select **App registrations** > **Deleted applications**. Select the application registration to restore, and then select **Restore app registration**.\n+To restore an application from the Microsoft Entra admin center, browse to **Entra ID** > **App registrations** > **Deleted applications**. Select the application registration to restore, and then select **Restore app registration**.\n \n-Currently, service principals can be listed, viewed, hard deleted, or restored via the deletedItems Microsoft Graph API. To restore applications using Microsoft Graph, see [Restore deleted item - Microsoft Graph v1.0.](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-restore?tabs=http).\n+Service principals can be listed, viewed, hard deleted, or restored using the deletedItems Microsoft Graph API. To restore applications using Microsoft Graph, see [Restore deleted item - Microsoft Graph v1.0.](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-restore?tabs=http).\n \n ### Administrative units\n \n-AUs can be listed, viewed, or restored via the deletedItems Microsoft Graph API. To restore AUs using Microsoft Graph, see [Restore deleted item - Microsoft Graph v1.0.](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-restore?tabs=http). Once an AU is deleted it remains in a soft deleted state and can be restored for 30 days, but cannot be hard deleted during that time. Soft deleted AUs are hard deleted automatically after 30 days.\n+Administrative units can be listed, viewed, or restored via the deletedItems Microsoft Graph API. To restore administrative units using Microsoft Graph, see [Restore deleted item - Microsoft Graph v1.0.](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-restore?tabs=http). When an administrative unit is deleted, it remains in a soft-deleted state and can be restored for 30 days but can't be hard deleted during that time. Soft deleted administrative units are hard deleted automatically after 30 days.\n+\n+### Conditional Access policies\n+\n+You should review and validate the Conditional Access policy configuration after restoring to ensure it behaves as expected.\n+\n+To restore a Conditional access policy:\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Conditional Access Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator).\n+1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Conditional Access** > **Deleted Policies (Preview**).\n+1. Select the ellipsis (...) on the far right of the policy to restore.\n+1. Select **Restore**.\n+1. In the **Restore Conditional Access policy?** dialog box, you can choose to restore the policy in [Report-only mode](../identity/conditional-access/concept-conditional-access-report-only.md) or leave it in the state it was when deleted, which might be **On**. Make your selection and select **Restore**.\n+\n+> [!WARNING]\n+> Restoring a policy to its previous state might have unintended consequences. Microsoft recommends administrators restore their policies in Report-only mode first, then take time to review and enable.\n+\n+### Named locations\n+\n+Named locations can't be deleted when marked as trusted, and when recovered from soft-delete, they aren't marked as trusted. Any recovered named locations should be reviewed after restoring before marking as trusted again.\n+\n+To restore a named location:\n+\n+1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Conditional Access Administrator](~/identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator).\n+1. Browse to **Entra ID** > **Conditional Access** > **Named locations** > **Deleted Named Locations (Preview)**.\n+1. Select the ellipsis (...) on the far right of the location you want to restore.\n+1. Select **Restore**.\n+1. In the **Restore selected Named location?** dialog box, select **Restore**.\n \n ## Hard deletions\n \n-A hard deletion is the permanent removal of an object from your Microsoft Entra tenant. Objects that don't support soft delete are removed in this way. Similarly, soft-deleted objects are hard deleted after a deletion time of 30 days. The only object types that support a soft delete are:\n+A hard deletion permanently removes an object from your Microsoft Entra tenant. Objects that don't support soft delete are removed in this way. Soft-deleted objects are also hard deleted after 30 days. Only these object types support soft delete:\n \n * Users\n * Microsoft 365 Groups\n * Application registration\n * Service principal\n * Administrative unit\n+* Conditional Access policies\n+* Named locations\n \n > [!IMPORTANT]\n-> All other item types are hard deleted. When an item is hard deleted, it can't be restored. It must be re-created. Neither administrators nor Microsoft can restore hard-deleted items. Prepare for this situation by ensuring that you have processes and documentation to minimize potential disruption from a hard delete.\n+> All other item types are hard deleted and can't be restored. They must be re-created. **Your administrators and Microsoft can't restore hard-deleted items**. Prepare by creating processes and documentation to minimize disruption.\n >\n > For information on how to prepare for and document current states, see [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md).\n \n ### When hard deletes usually occur\n \n-Hard deletes might occur in the following circumstances.\n+Hard deletes can occur in these circumstances:\n \n Moving from soft to hard delete:\n \n-* A soft-deleted object wasn't restored within 30 days.\n+* A soft-deleted object isn't restored within 30 days.\n * An administrator intentionally deletes an object in the soft delete state.\n \n Directly hard deleted:\n \n * The object type that was deleted doesn't support soft delete.\n * An administrator chooses to permanently delete an item by using the portal, which typically occurs in response to a request.\n-* An automation script triggers the deletion of the object by using Microsoft Graph or PowerShell. Use of an automation script to clean up stale objects isn't uncommon. A robust off-boarding process for objects in your tenant helps you to avoid mistakes that might result in mass deletion of critical objects.\n+* An automation script triggers the deletion of the object using Microsoft Graph or PowerShell. Automation scripts are commonly used to clean up stale objects. A robust off-boarding process helps avoid mistakes that can result in mass deletion of critical objects.\n \n ## Recover from hard deletion\n \n-Hard-deleted items must be re-created and reconfigured. It's best to avoid unwanted hard deletions.\n+Hard-deleted items need to be recreated and reconfigured. Avoiding unwanted hard deletions is best.\n \n ### Review soft-deleted objects\n \n-Ensure you have a process to frequently review items in the soft-delete state and restore them if appropriate. To do so, you should:\n+Make sure you have a process to regularly review items in the soft-delete state and restore them if needed. To prepare:\n \n-* Frequently [list deleted items](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-list?tabs=http).\n-* Ensure that you have specific criteria for what should be restored.\n-* Ensure that you have specific roles or users assigned to evaluate and restore items as appropriate.\n-* Develop and test a continuity management plan. For more information, see [Considerations for your Enterprise Business Continuity Management Plan](/compliance/assurance/assurance-developing-your-ebcm-plan).\n+* Regularly [list deleted items](/graph/api/directory-deleteditems-list?tabs=http).\n+* Define specific criteria for what to restore.\n+* Assign specific roles or users to evaluate and restore items as needed.\n+* Create and test a continuity management plan. Learn more in [Considerations for your Enterprise Business Continuity Management Plan](/compliance/assurance/assurance-developing-your-ebcm-plan).\n \n-For more information on how to avoid unwanted deletions, see the following articles in [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md):\n+## Next steps\n \n-* Business continuity and disaster planning\n-* Document known good states\n-* Monitoring and data retention\n+Learn how to avoid unwanted deletions in, [Recoverability best practices](recoverability-overview.md).\n\\ No newline at end of file" }, { "sha": "ce0415addfe3ad72a6083232b30425c890d826f3", "filename": "docs/fundamentals/whats-new.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 10, "deletions": 0, "changes": 10, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md?ref=73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587", "patch": "@@ -24,6 +24,16 @@ This article provides information about the latest releases and change announcem\n \n ## September 2025\n \n+### Public Preview - Convert Source of Authority of synced Active Directory users to the cloud\n+\n+**Type:** New feature \n+**Service category:** User Management \n+**Product capability:** Microsoft Entra Connect and Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync\n+\n+The Source of Authority (SOA) at the object level allows administrators to convert specific users synced from Active Directory (AD) to Microsoft Entra ID into cloud-editable objects, which are no longer synced from AD and act as if originally created in the cloud. This feature supports a gradual migration process, decreasing dependencies on AD while aiming to minimize user and operational impact. Both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync recognize the SOA switch for these objects. The option to switch the SOA of synced users from AD to Microsoft Entra ID is currently available in Public Preview. For more information, see: [Embrace cloud-first posture: Transfer user Source of Authority (SOA) to the cloud (Preview)](../identity/hybrid/user-source-of-authority-overview.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n ### Public Preview - Use SMS as a verification method in password reset flows in Microsoft Entra External ID \n \n **Type:** New feature " }, { "sha": "737014ce1e83eb9b83d0e09b9cb0d8824441a58a", manager: pmwongera\n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: app-provisioning\n ms.topic: tutorial\n-ms.date: 03/04/2025\n+ms.date: 10/06/2025\n ms.custom: template-tutorial, sfi-image-nochange\n ms.reviewer: arvinh\n ai-usage: ai-assisted\n@@ -73,6 +73,87 @@ Finally, you need to test and validate your endpoint.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"./media/scim-validator-tutorial/scim-validator-results.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of SCIM Validator results page.\" lightbox=\"./media/scim-validator-tutorial/scim-validator-results.png\":::\n \n+### Note validations performed by SCIM Validator\n+\n+**Create New User**\n+- POST /Users â€“ Creates a new user with a complete JSON payload.\n+ - Endpoint returns HTTP 201\n+ - POST response contains created user ID\n+- GET /Users?filter={joiningProperty} eq \"value\" â€“ Verifies creation by filtering on the joining property.\n+ - GET returns created user\n+ - Returned values from GET match the passed values from the POST request (varies based on endpoint)\n+- DELETE /Users - Cleans Up Test User.\t\n+ -Only called if hard delete is supported\n+ \n+**Create Duplicate User**\t\n+- POST /Users â€“ Attempts to create a user using an identical payload (with the same unique/joining attribute) to an existing user.\n+ - Return HTTP 201 on first create request\n+ - Return HTTP 409 on second create request\n+\n+**Add Attributes**\n+- POST /Users - Creates the user resource\n+ - HTTP 2xx success\n+- PATCH /Users/{id} â€“ Uses a JSON Patch document (with the add operation) to insert additional non-required attributes.\n+- GET /Users?filter={joiningProperty} eq \"value\" â€“ Retrieves the user to verify the added attributes.\n+ - User is returned\n+ - Inserted attributes are now present on the user\n+ \n+**Replace User Attributes**\n+- POST /Users - Creates the user resource\n+ - HTTP 2xx success\n+- PATCH /Users/{id} â€“ Sends a JSON Patch document (using the replace operation) to update one or more attributes.\n+- GET /Users?filter={joiningProperty} eq \"value\" â€“ Verifies that the updated attributes are correctly applied.\n+ - User is returned\n+ - Updated attributes are present on the user\n+ \n+**Update Joining Property**\n+- POST /Users - Creates the user resource\n+ - HTTP 2xx success\n+- PATCH /Users/{id} â€“ Updates the joining property (e.g., userName) via a JSON Patch document.\n+- GET /Users?filter={joiningProperty} eq \"newValue\" â€“ Confirms the joining property has been updated.\t\n+ - Joining property is updated on user\n+\n+**Update Active Attribute to False**\n+- POST /Users/ - Creates a resource based on the schema\n+ - HTTP 2xx success\n+ - Disabled user should be returned on GET request\n+- PATCH /Users/{id} â€“ Issues a JSON Patch document that sets the \"active\" attribute to false.\n+ - HTTP 2xx success\n+- GET /Users?filter={joiningProperty} eq \"value\" â€“ Retrieves the user to confirm the active attribute is now false.\t\n+ - Returned user record should have ACTIVE=FALSE\"\n+\n+**Create New Group**\n+- POST /Groups â€“ Creates a new group with a complete JSON payload.\n+ - Endpoint returns HTTP 201\n+ - POST response contains created group ID\n+- GET /Group?filter={joiningProperty} eq \"value\" â€“ Verifies creation by filtering on the joining property.\n+ - GET returns created group\n+ - Returned values from GET match the passed values from the POST request (varies based on endpoint)\n+- DELETE /Groups - Cleans Up Test User.\t\n+ - Only called if hard delete is supported\n+\n+**Create Duplicate Group**\t\n+- POST /Groups â€“ Attempts to create a group using an identical payload (with the same unique/joining attribute) to an existing group.\n+ - Return HTTP 201 on first create request\n+ - Return HTTP 409 on second create request\n+\n+**Update Group Attributes**\n+- POST /Groups - Creates a new group resource to update attributes on\n+ - POST Returns HTTP 2xx\n+- PATCH /Groups/{id} â€“ Sends a JSON Patch document using the replace operation to update one or more attributes of an existing group (excluding members).\n+ - PATCH returns success (HTTP 2xx)\n+- GET /Groups?filter={joiningProperty} eq \"value\" â€“ Confirms that the groupâ€™s attributes have been updated correctly.\n+ - GET returns patched group\n+ - Attributes on returned group match changed attributes on PATCH request\n+\n+**Create a New Group Resource**\n+- POST /Groups - Creates a new group resource to add member to\n+ - POST Returns HTTP 2xx\n+- POST /Users â€“ Creates a new user resource to be used as a group member.\n+ - POST Returns HTTP 2xx\n+- PATCH /Groups/{id} â€“ Adds the newly created userâ€™s identifier to the group using a JSON Patch document.\n+ - PATCH Returns success\n+\n ## Using Expressions on SCIM Validator\n The SCIM Validator supports using expressions to generate desired values for attributes.\n " article provides example SCIM requests emitted by the Microsoft Entra provi\n - Returned values from GET match the passed values from the POST request (varies based on endpoint)\n - DELETE /Groups - Cleans Up Test User.\t\n - Only called if hard delete is supported\n- \n+\n **Create Duplicate Group**\t\n - POST /Groups â€“ Attempts to create a group using an identical payload (with the same unique/joining attribute) to an existing group.\n - Return HTTP 201 on first create request\n@@ -801,6 +801,7 @@ This article provides example SCIM requests emitted by the Microsoft Entra provi\n \n ##### Validations performed by SCIM Validator\n \n+**Update Group Attributes**\n - POST /Groups - Creates a new group resource to update attributes on\n - POST Returns HTTP 2xx\n - PATCH /Groups/{id} â€“ Sends a JSON Patch document using the replace operation to update one or more attributes of an existing group (excluding members).\n@@ -835,6 +836,8 @@ This article provides example SCIM requests to add member to\n - POST Returns HTTP 2xx\n - POST /Users â€“ Creates a new user resource to be used as a group member." }, { "sha": "d8b9dd65bb4b93b68ee19d5caed1ee7c633b283b", "filename": Use this setting when the policy using the named location should apply to unknown locations.\n \n+## Restore deleted locations\n+\n+If a Conditional Access policy or location is deleted, it can be restored within the 30 day soft-delete period. "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fmedia%2Fguidance-it-architects-source-of-authority%2Fsource-of-authority-readiness-diagram.png", }, { "sha": "35f2f8cb49447004685adcf7fcc5cc8e66f3dddf", "filename": "docs/identity/hybrid/user-source-of-authority-overview.md", "status": "modified", "additions": 1, "deletions": 1, "changes": 2, "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fuser-source-of-authority-overview.md", "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fuser-source-of-authority-overview.md", "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fhybrid%2Fuser-source-of-authority-overview.md?ref=73e91a8b87b9ab94b2a71f8dfc28a1d2bf13f587", "patch": "@@ -31,7 +31,7 @@ The next sections explain more details about the scenario that User SOA supports\n \n ### Password-less authentication of SOA transferred users\n \n-**Scenario**: Youâ€™ve transferred the SOA for users and now want to allow them to access both on-premises, and cloud, resources. Instead of completely removing users from on-premises, introduce Cloud Kerberos Trust password-less authentication to allow them to maintain a hybrid presence allowing them to continue to access their on-premises resources, while also allowing them to access cloud resources. Password-less authentication methods, such as [Windows Hello for Business](/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/configure) or [FIDO2 security keys](../../identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2.md), can be used to allow these users to access both their on-premises resources, and cloud resources such as [Azure Files](/azure/storage/files/storage-files-introduction) through [Microsoft Entra Private Access](../../global-secure-access/concept-private-access.md). Using Password-less authentication also enables Multifactor Authentication on the SOA transferred users increasing security. Password-less authentication also allows you to enable Conditional Access policies on the on-premises resources, allowing greater control and security over these resources.\n+**Scenario**: Youâ€™ve transferred the SOA for users and now want to allow them to access both on-premises, and cloud, resources. Instead of completely removing users from on-premises, introduce Cloud Kerberos Trust password-less authentication to allow them to maintain a hybrid presence allowing them to continue to access their on-premises resources, while also allowing them to access cloud resources. Password-less authentication methods, such as [Windows Hello for Business](/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/configure) or [FIDO2 security keys](../../identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2.md), can be used to allow these users to access both their on-premises resources, and cloud resources such as [Azure Files](/azure/storage/files/storage-files-introduction) through [Microsoft Entra Private Access](../../global-secure-access/concept-private-access.md). Using Password-less authentication also enables Multifactor Authentication on the SOA transferred users increasing security. Password-less authentication also allows you to enable Conditional Access policies on the on-premises resources, allowing greater control and security over these resources. **The user account must remain in Active Directory for this scenario to work**.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/user-source-of-authority-overview/passwordless-authentication-source-of-authority.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the password-less authentication scenario for User SOA.\":::\n " } ]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit includes several updates to Microsoft Entra ID documentation. Primarily, there's a significant revision to the "Recover from deletions" article, enhancing clarity on soft vs. hard deletions and restoration procedures. Additionally, updates have been made to "What's new" to include a new public preview feature for converting synced AD users to cloud-editable, and improvements to SCIM provisioning tutorials. Minor adjustments are present in articles concerning certificate-based authentication, Conditional Access policies, and hybrid identity guidance.

message:
Merge pull request #9918 from OWinfreyATL/owinfreyATL-WhatsNewSOA

User SOA added to whats new

ai_summary.Messages:
{"role":"user","content":"The following is the commit files that have changed: {
  "sha": "ce0415addfe3ad72a6083232b30425c890d826f3",
  "filename": "docs/fundamentals/whats-new.md",
  "status": "modified",
  "additions": 10,
  "deletions": 0,
  "changes": 10,
  "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/3193bf6fe0e54189995dba84997850e50f9afc60/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md",
  "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/3193bf6fe0e54189995dba84997850e50f9afc60/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md",
  "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md?ref=3193bf6fe0e54189995dba84997850e50f9afc60",
  "patch": "@@ -24,6 +24,16 @@ This article provides information about the latest releases and change announcem\n \n ## September 2025\n \n+### Public Preview - Convert Source of Authority of synced Active Directory users to the cloud\n+\n+**Type:** New feature  \n+**Service category:** User Management  \n+**Product capability:** Microsoft Entra Connect and Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync\n+\n+The Source of Authority (SOA) at the object level allows administrators to convert specific users synced from Active Directory (AD) to Microsoft Entra ID into cloud-editable objects, which are no longer synced from AD and act as if originally created in the cloud. This feature supports a gradual migration process, decreasing dependencies on AD while aiming to minimize user and operational impact. Both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync recognize the SOA switch for these objects. The option to switch the SOA of synced users from AD to Microsoft Entra ID is currently available in Public Preview. For more information, see: [Embrace cloud-first posture: Transfer user Source of Authority (SOA) to the cloud (Preview)](../identity/hybrid/user-source-of-authority-overview.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n ### Public Preview - Use SMS as a verification method in password reset flows in Microsoft Entra External ID \n \n **Type:** New feature    "
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: This commit introduces a new feature to Microsoft Entra ID, currently in public preview. Administrators can now convert the source of authority for synced Active Directory users to the cloud. This allows specific users to become cloud-editable, reducing their dependency on Active Directory and facilitating a more gradual migration to a cloud-first posture. Both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync will recognise this change.

This feature supports a gradual migration process, decreasing dependencies on AD while aiming to minimize user and operational impact. Both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync recognize the SOA switch for these objects. The option to switch the SOA of synced users from AD to Microsoft Entra ID is currently available in Public Preview. For more information, see: [Embrace cloud-first posture: Transfer user Source of Authority (SOA) to the cloud (Preview)](../identity/hybrid/user-source-of-authority-overview.md)."
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response: A recent update to the Microsoft Entra documentation (`docs/fundamentals/whats-new.md`) has reclassified the 'Convert Source of Authority of synced Active Directory users to the cloud' feature. Previously listed under 'Group Management', this new capability, which allows for transitioning synced AD users to cloud-editable objects, is now correctly categorised under 'User Management'. This change reflects the feature's core functionality in managing user identities.

Instead of completely removing users from on-premises, introduce Cloud Kerberos Trust password-less authentication to allow them to maintain a hybrid presence allowing them to continue to access their on-premises resources, while also allowing them to access cloud resources. Password-less authentication methods, such as [Windows Hello for Business](/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/configure) or [FIDO2 security keys](../../identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2.md), can be used to allow these users to access both their on-premises resources, and cloud resources such as [Azure Files](/azure/storage/files/storage-files-introduction) through [Microsoft Entra Private Access](../../global-secure-access/concept-private-access.md). Using Password-less authentication also enables Multifactor Authentication on the SOA transferred users increasing security. Password-less authentication methods, such as [Windows Hello for Business](/windows/security/identity-protection/hello-for-business/configure) or [FIDO2 security keys](../../identity/authentication/how-to-enable-passkey-fido2.md), can be used to allow these users to access both their on-premises resources, and cloud resources such as [Azure Files](/azure/storage/files/storage-files-introduction) through [Microsoft Entra Private Access](../../global-secure-access/concept-private-access.md). Using Password-less authentication also enables Multifactor Authentication on the SOA transferred users increasing security. Password-less authentication also allows you to enable Conditional Access policies on the on-premises resources, allowing greater control and security over these resources. **The user account must remain in Active Directory for this scenario to work**.\n  \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/user-source-of-authority-overview/passwordless-authentication-source-of-authority.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the password-less authentication scenario for User SOA.\":::\n "

]. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response:
This commit modifies documentation related to hybrid identity and source of authority (SOA) for users.

Firstly, the `guidance-it-architects-source-of-authority.md` file sees a minor adjustment to the alt-text of an image, improving its description.

Secondly, the `user-source-of-authority-overview.md` file has a key clarification added to the "Password-less authentication of SOA transferred users" scenario. It now explicitly states that **the user account must remain in Active Directory for this scenario to work**.

author: Ortagus Winfrey
message: User SOA added to whats new

  "deletions": 0,
  "changes": 10,
  "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/3a81cbceea8b71d809c336e7f9e62dd0e6abf81c/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md",
  "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/3a81cbceea8b71d809c336e7f9e62dd0e6abf81c/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md",
  "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fwhats-new.md?ref=3a81cbceea8b71d809c336e7f9e62dd0e6abf81c",
  "patch": "@@ -24,6 +24,16 @@ This article provides information about the latest releases and change announcem\n \n ## September 2025\n \n+### Public Preview - Convert Source of Authority of synced Active Directory users to the cloud\n+\n+**Type:** New feature  \n+**Service category:** Group Management  \n+**Product capability:** Microsoft Entra Connect and Microsoft Entra Cloud Sync\n+\n+The Source of Authority (SOA) at the object level allows administrators to convert specific users synced from Active Directory (AD) to Microsoft Entra ID into cloud-editable objects, which are no longer synced from AD and act as if originally created in the cloud. This feature supports a gradual migration process, decreasing dependencies on AD while aiming to minimize user and operational impact. Both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync recognize the SOA switch for these objects. The option to switch the SOA of synced users from AD to Microsoft Entra ID is currently available in Public Preview. For more information, see: [Embrace cloud-first posture: Transfer user Source of Authority (SOA) to the cloud (Preview)](../identity/hybrid/user-source-of-authority-overview.md).\n+\n+---\n+\n ### Public Preview - Use SMS as a verification method in password reset flows in Microsoft Entra External ID \n \n **Type:** New feature    "
}. Please summarise it in a few sentences, using UK grammar and ensure the response is formatted for markdown. Do not start the response with here is summary."}
ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the changes:

This commit introduces a new feature to the documentation for Microsoft Entra ID. It details the public preview of a capability allowing administrators to convert the source of authority for synced Active Directory users to Microsoft Entra ID. This enables these users to become cloud-editable, reducing dependency on on-premises Active Directory and facilitating a gradual migration towards a cloud-first posture, with support for both Microsoft Entra Connect Sync and Cloud Sync.

  "patch": "@@ -99,6 +99,9 @@ Certain Exchange ActiveSync applications on Android 5.0 (Lollipop) or later are\n |Edge browser with profile login\t |  ✅ |\n |Managed Home Screen\t |  ✅ |\n \n+>[!NOTE]\n+>When using Microsoft Entra certificate-based authentication on Android devices in kiosk mode (common in Shared Device Mode), customers should allow list com.android.systemui as a required package to ensure they are presented with the appropriate UI to complete their authentication. \n+\n ### Browsers\n \n |Operating system | Chrome certificate on-device | Chrome smart card/security key | Safari certificate on-device | Safari smart card/security key | Edge certificate on-device | Edge smart card/security key |"

ai_summary.Response:
Here's a summary of the changes:

A new note has been added to the documentation concerning certificate-based authentication on Android devices. It specifically advises that for devices operating in kiosk mode, such as those using Shared Device Mode, the `com.android.systemui` package should be allow-listed. This is to ensure users are correctly presented with the necessary user interface for authentication completion.

ai_summary.Response: This commit updates the documentation for certificate-based authentication on Android. A new note has been added to advise users that when implementing this authentication method on Android devices in kiosk mode, they should add `com.android.systemui` to a allow list. This is to ensure the correct user interface is displayed for completing the authentication process.
